div.p: ANTONIO: So in the Orange Phase a person may relate to the alcohol or drugs like a friend or even a lover.

FROSTY: Right, and when we think about how psychological dependence is similar to a love relationship, we can understand how strongly the person in the Orange Phase will defend their high-risk choices.
FROSTY: It's similar to the way we'd defend a relationship with a friend or family member we want to protect.
EJNA: So we might rationalize problems in various ways, making them seem minor or a small price to pay for the pleasure of drinking or drug use.
EJNA: And we are not likely to go places where our drinking or drug choices are criticized or unwelcome, just as we would not go somewhere a person we loved was not welcome.
EJNA: We are more likely to choose settings where people accept our high-risk choices.
NARRATOR: There are many ways we might rationalize our choices. For example, I might be in the Orange Phase but believe I'm in the Yellow or even the Green Phase.
NARRATOR: How have I tricked myself? One way is that I might think I'm making low-risk choices. When in reality, I don't bother to count my drinks, or to measure standard drinks when I do count.
NARRATOR: Or, I may use a glass that holds two or three standard drinks, but I count it as one. And if I have a fourth or fifth glass, I don't really pay much attention.
NARRATOR: In fact, I might be sort of "grazing" my way through the evening, having one drink or drug after another but not really counting at all.
NARRATOR: Combine all of these, and I might be drinking 6-10 standard drinks and still not think of myself as high-risk drinker. This is one common way defense mechanisms can work.
